title: EnvLeadership&Biography
description: This course will ask students to reflect on how they can develop the human dimension of environmental leadership in themselves and others. Through exploring the lives of historic environmental leaders (e.g., John Muir, Gifford Pinchot, Aldo Leopold, Rachel Carson) through biography and hearing contemporary leaders (e.g., Gus Speth, Frances Beinecke, Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, Terry Tempest Williams) reflect on their own experiences, we will explore how life narratives evolve based on the values that individuals cultivate in their own lives and their engagement with the historical context in which they operate, as well as the strategies leaders use to create positive social change. In these lives, we are hoping to draw out themes such as the cultivation of personal and social values; how narrative, and in particular personal narrative, can be leveraged to create social change; how goals are set and strategically accomplished; how and on what basis are decisions made; strategies for building relationships and inspiring others to join your cause. Some classes will be co-taught with leading faculty from elsewhere at Yale (e.g., History, School of Management). There will also be a panel on Women in Environmental Leadership moderated by the Senior Fellow of the Yale Corporation, Margaret Marshall, who previously served as the Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Students will be encouraged to engage with other environmental leaders visiting F&ES during the fall semester, particularly those visiting in conjunction with F&ES792a âStructuring Success: Skills and People Required to Convert Social Ideas into Positive Community Reality.â For one or three credits.
